Fighting Chronic Lung Infections in Cystic Fibrosis Patients: Garlic has been shown to inhibit Pseudomonas aeruginosa, one of the most common causes of chronic lung infections in cystic fibrosis patients. It works by disrupting a bacterial communication system called quorum sensing, which enables bacteria to form biofilms—tenacious colonies of bacteria that persist in the lungs. Quorum sensing molecules also activate bacterial virulence factors such as elastase, an enzyme that breaks down elastic tissue in the lungs. This research was led by Alan Smyth, from the School of Human Development at the University of Nottingham.
Notes:
Single clove garlic (garlic onion) is produced by planting an immature garlic clove or unfavorable planting conditions. Yunan province of China is a major producer of single clove garlic. Historical records indicate that Zhang Qian brought garlic back to the Central Plains during his diplomatic missions to the Western Regions. Zhang Qian (164 BCE – 114 BCE) was a native of Chenggu in Hanzhong Commandery (present-day Chenggu County, Shaanxi Province). In the second year of the reign of Emperor Wu of Han (139 BCE), the imperial court recruited envoys to the Western Regions, and Zhang Qian volunteered for the mission in his capacity as a court officer (langguan). Some of the sulfur-containing compounds and ascorbic acid (vitamin C) present in garlic can enhance the activity of endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS), thereby promoting vasodilation (relaxation of blood vessels).
 Lipid- and Blood Sugar-Lowering Effects: Garlic extract has been shown to significantly reduce blood lipids and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) levels in rabbits with hyperlipidemia, while increasing high-density lipoprotein (HDL). It also reduces lipid accumulation in the aorta by 72% and markedly shrinks atherosclerotic plaques, showing better results than Clofibrate (also known as Clofibric acid, Atromid-S, or Antuoming). Garlic essential oil has proven effective in combating elevated blood lipids, helping maintain normal cholesterol and triglyceride levels in both serum and liver. This effect may be related to the reduction of cholesterol esterification in the bloodstream. Additionally, garlic influences liver glycogen synthesis and raises plasma insulin levels, offering significant therapeutic benefits for diabetic patients. 
 Cardiovascular Effects: A number of recent animal studies and clinical trials consistently demonstrate that garlic—particularly its active compound, allicin—has a significant antihypertensive effect. It improves microcirculation, increases peripheral blood flow, and enhances the activity of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), which promotes fibrinolysis. Garlic also inhibits the activity of clotting factors, lowers plasma malondialdehyde (MDA) levels, and exhibits strong anti-atherosclerotic properties. Additionally, garlic essential oil provides protective benefits against aortic atherosclerosis caused by hypercholesterolemia. 
 Antimicrobial Effects: Garlic is often referred to as a natural antibiotic due to its broad-spectrum activity against various pathogenic microorganisms. It can effectively kill or inhibit Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus, Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Shigella, Salmonella typhi, Escherichia coli, and Vibrio cholerae, among others—without leading to drug resistance. The most potent antimicrobial agents in garlic are allicin and its essential oil components with a refractive index above 1.57. Garlic extracts also show varying degrees of inhibitory effects on common pathogenic skin fungi. Some researchers suggest that its antimicrobial activity is partly due to a non-volatile, oily compound with antibiotic-like properties. Moreover, garlic exhibits a strong inhibitory effect against cytomegalovirus (CMV), with its potency increasing proportionally to concentration. 
 Anti-Aging Effects: Some studies have compared the medicinal properties of garlic and ginseng, particularly in their antioxidant capacity. In vitro experiments have shown that alliin and ethanol extracts of garlic exhibit stronger antioxidant activity than ginseng. In vivo, garlic demonstrated superior inhibition of superoxide dismutase activity in the liver, although its antioxidant performance in the brain was slightly lower than that of ginseng. These findings suggest that garlic may play a meaningful role in delaying the aging process. 
 Immune Function: Research indicates that allicin can induce the transformation of human lymphocytes. Natural garlic extract has been shown to promote T-lymphocyte activation and enhance the functional activity of both macrophages and lymphocytes. As a result, garlic contributes to the strengthening of the immune system. 
 Anti-Platelet Aggregation Effect: Consumption of allicin has been shown to significantly reduce platelet adhesion rates and noticeably prolong blood clotting time in animal studies. Garlic essential oil also exhibits thrombolytic properties and effectively inhibits platelet aggregation, contributing to improved circulatory health. 
 Anti-Tumor Effects: Recent studies have shown that oral intake of garlic oil can inhibit the development of skin cancer induced by chemical carcinogens such as benzo(a)pyrene. This effect may be achieved by suppressing the activation of the aryl hydroxylase enzyme system during the initiation stage of carcinogenesis, thereby blocking the mutagenic transformation of normal cells. Research also indicates that garlic interferes with pre-cancerous liver conditions caused by nitrosamines. Garlic oil supports the normal division and repair of cellular DNA, and its absence may lead to DNA abnormalities, increasing the risk of cancers such as lung, liver, and esophageal cancer. Additionally, garlic oil enhances the number of neutrophils and macrophages, strengthening the immune defense. Consuming raw garlic can inhibit nitrate-reducing bacteria in the stomach, thereby reducing the nitrites formed by bacterial activity. Two critical anti-cancer compounds in garlic—diallyl sulfide and calcium salts—help prevent carcinogen formation, disrupt carcinogen activation, boost detoxification, and eliminate reactive metabolites. These actions, combined with garlic’s ability to stimulate immune responses, block peroxide generation, and inhibit abnormal cell proliferation, contribute to the prevention and suppression of tumor development. 
 Detoxification Effects: Recent studies have explored the use of garlic in treating heavy metal poisoning. In one case, administering 0.3 grams of garlic tablets orally, three times a day, achieved a 100% effective rate in treating lead poisoning. Additionally, research on changes in ATPase activity in mice exposed to mercury revealed that garlic also has a strong antagonistic effect against mercury toxicity, indicating its potential as a natural detoxifying agent. 
 Other Effects: Garlic also exhibits protective properties, such as anti-radiation effects and protection of biological membranes. A 0.5% garlic solution can render Trichomonas vaginalis inactive within 5 minutes. It is also useful for the prevention and treatment of conditions such as dry periodontitis, epistaxis, colds, and chronic gastritis. Additionally, garlic extract has been shown to increase the mortality rate of Aedes mosquito larvae, and a one-millionth concentration of garlic extract can repel female mosquitoes.
Chemical Ingredients: 1. Evaporating Oil Components: Garlic contains a wide range of volatile sulfur compounds. These include allyl methyl sulfide, diallyl sulfide, 6-methyl-1-thio-2,4-cyclohexadiene, dimethyl sulfide, divinyl sulfide, dimethyl disulfide, allyl methyl disulfide, dithiocyclopentene, 5-methyl-1,2-dithio-3-cyclopentene, allyl propyl disulfide, 4-methyl-1,2-dithio-3-cyclopentene, 3-vinyl-1,2-dithio-4-cyclohexene, 3-vinyl-1,2-dithio-5-cyclohexene, dimethyl trisulfide, allyl methyl trisulfide, 4-vinyl-1,2,3-trithio-5-cyclohexene, diallyl trisulfide, allyl propyl trisulfide, diallyl tetrasulfide, dipropyl disulfide, methyl propyl trisulfide, allyl methyl tetrasulfide, and allyl methyl pentasulfide. Additionally, garlic oil contains non-sulfur compounds like allicin, sulfur dioxide, 2-hydroxy-propyl, cymene, trans-ajoene, cis-ajoene, 2-vinyl-4-H-1,3-dithiin, and 3-vinyl-4-H-1,2-dithiin.

2. Carbohydrates: The carbohydrate content of garlic includes simple sugars such as glucose, fructose, galactose, sucrose, and raffinose. It also contains starch, garlic dextrin, and garlic sugar. Four key types of polysaccharides are found: D-galactan, D-fructan, D-glucan, and D-arabinan. From garlic, five specific polysaccharides have been isolated and identified as GF-1, GF-II, GF-III, GF-IVa, and GF-IV.

3. Peptides and Amino Acids: Garlic is rich in amino acids, notably those with higher concentrations like cysteine, histidine, and lysine. One of the key sulfur-containing amino acids found is alliin, also known as S-allyl-cysteine sulfoxide. When garlic is enzymatically hydrolyzed, alliin is converted into allicin, the compound responsible for garlic’s distinctive aroma and antimicrobial properties. Six polypeptides have also been identified in garlic: A, B, C, D, E, and F.

4. Enzymes:A variety of enzymes are naturally present in garlic. The most significant is alliinase, which catalyzes the transformation of alliin into allicin. Other enzymes in garlic include peroxidase, hydrolases, polyphenol oxidase, hexokinase, polyfructose glycoside hydrolase, invertase, phosphatase, pectin esterase, and trypsin. These enzymes contribute to garlic’s metabolic activities and therapeutic effects.

5. 5. Glucosinolates: Garlic contains multiple glucosinolate compounds, collectively known as scordinins. Specific types that have been isolated include scordinin A2, A3, B1, B2, and B3. These compounds are known for their biological activity and may contribute to garlic’s immune-enhancing and anticancer properties.

6. Steroidal Glycosides: Several steroidal glycosides have been isolated from garlic. Proeruboside B is one, with a structure identified as 26-O-β-D-glucopyranosyl-22-hydroxy-25-(R)-5α-furostane-3β,6β,26-triol-3-O-β-D-glucopyranosyl-(1→2)-[β-D-glucopyranosyl-(1→3)]-β-D-glucopyranosyl-(1→4)-β-D-galactopyranoside. Sativoside-R1 and Sativoside-R2 (tigogenin-based) are additional glycosides that contribute to the plant’s medicinal properties, particularly in modulating cholesterol and steroidal metabolism.

7. Oxalic Acid: Garlic contains oxalic acid at a concentration of 0.36 grams per 100 grams of fresh garlic. Though found in relatively low amounts, oxalic acid is an organic acid that naturally occurs in many plants and plays a role in mineral binding and bioavailability.
